Award.AwardTitle: Insight into mitochondria function and evolution from studies of a plant pathogenic stramenopile

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
In eukaryotes, metabolic reactions are typically partitioned between different cellular compartments. One set of metabolic reactions thought to occur only in the cytoplasm is glycolysis, the chemical reactions that generate cellular energy. In this project, the PI will investigate a deviation from this well-accepted textbook definition of glycolysis in Oomycetes, a group of plant and animal pathogens, in which part of glycolysis is proposed to occur in mitochondria. The project will provide a better understanding of the origins and diversity of these metabolic reactions in the potato pathogen Phytophthora infestans. The novel oomycete metabolic pathways that will be studied also represent potential targets for inhibitors that can be exploited to develop new disease control strategies. This will yield economic and environmental benefits, raise the sustainability of agricultural production, and increase food security. The project also supports scientific education and the training of a diverse workforce through the participation of graduate and undergraduate students at a Hispanic-Serving Institution.

Our current understanding of glycolysis is based largely on a few model organisms. This project focuses on the role of mitochondria and metabolic compartmentalization in that organelle in glycolysis, using as a model the potato pathogen Phytophthora infestans. This filamentous eukaryotic microbe is a member of the oomycete group of the stramenopile kingdom. Since the evolutionary history of stramenopiles is distinct from that of classic model organisms, this project will shed light on the origins of mitochondria and diversity. The first objective of the project is to study glycolytic enzymes that are found in oomycete mitochondria. The classic view is that glycolysis takes place in the cytosol, but enzymes representing the payoff phase of glycolysis are predicted to also occur in oomycete mitochondria. These novel enzymes will be studied by localizing the relevant enzymes using fluorescent tags, silencing their genes, and assessing their activity. The second objective of the project is to examine P. infestans mitochondria more broadly with a goal of identifying other novel pathways in the organelle. The research will integrate evolutionary biology, cell biology, biochemistry, and molecular genetics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project shed light on the metabolism of an important potato pathogen, Phytophthora infestans. This filamentous eukaryotic microbe belongs to the under-studied Oomycete group. It is becoming increasingly clear that textbook descriptions of metabolism do not fully address eukaryotic diversity. Oomycetes have an evolutionary history that is distinct from that of model organisms. Our project provided insight into the origins and evolution of metabolic pathways, in addition to its broader impact of identifying metabolic pathways that might serve as targets for drugs and crop protection chemicals.

 

We identified several novel aspects of oomycete metabolism. For example, while the classic view is that glucose metabolism (glycolysis) takes place in the cytosol, we discovered that part of the pathway also occurs also in a separate organelle, mitochondria, in P. infestans and relatives. Other pathways that utilize glycolytic intermediates and in other organisms are based in cytoplasm, such as serine metabolism, have also been transferred to mitochondria in oomycetes. This novel finding forces scientists to rethink dogmas about how metabolism has become partitioned in different cellular compartments during eukaryotic evolution. Another novel aspect of oomycete metabolism is the use of a phosphagen kinase system. This allows the storage of energy in a novel compound, taurocyamine phosphate, and helps shuttle the energy currency between the site of its generation in mitochondria to flagella, a structure that provides the motile force to the swimming spore stage of the oomycete life cycle. Flagella use energy at a high rate during swimming, and thus the phosphagen kinase system enables oomycete pathogens to seek out new host plants. Interestingly, we also learned how P. infestans coordinated patterns of gene expression to allow taurocyamine to form from metabolic waste products that accumulate at the time of spore production. Besides focusing on these specific enzymes, we also reannotated the genome of P. infestans to better-catalog the metabolic capabilities of oomycetes, and used metabolite and gene expression data to simulate metabolic fluxes during plant infection and to identify the metabolic dependencies of P. infestans on its plant hosts.

 

Impacts of this project beyond studies of metabolism include a characterization of the strengths and limitations of techniques widely used by Phytophthora laboratories to study gene function, such as transformation and gene silencing. We also identified new methods for genome editing using modified CRISPR proteins, a system that uses natural DNA repair mechanisms to introduce mutations in genes. The project also provided training to six Ph.D. students and three undergraduates, many of which were first-generation college students or belonged to groups underrepresented in the sciences. Outreach activities were also conducted that provided information about research and careers in science to elementary, high school, and junior college students.
